001
002package com.commercetools.docs.meta;
003
004/**
005 * {@include.toc}
006 * <h2 id="representation">Representation</h2>
007 *
008 * The SDK provides types for each of the types described in the documentation of the REST API. Each type is represented
009 * by an interface, an implementation class and a builder class.
010 *
011 * <h3 id="interfaces">Interfaces</h3>
012 *
013 * The interface class describes the JSON structure by providing Getters and Setters. The necessary annotations to de-/serialize
014 * the JSON is defined here.
015 *
016 * Each interface has a factory method to create an instance of the implementation class and to copy an instance.
017 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#factoryMethod()}
018 *
019 * Also a model interface has a factory method to create a builder of a model instance or create a builder with the data of
020 * the instance itself. E.g.:
021 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#builderMethod()}
022 *
023 * And each interface has a method to apply a function to the instance itself. This can be used for custom defined accessors. E.g.:
024 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#accessorTest()}
025 *
026 * The model interfaces define the inheritance/composition structure of all documented types.
027 *
028 * <h4 id="polymorphic-types">Polymorphic types</h4>
029 *
030 * Each polymorphic type interface provides methods for all it's subtype builders
031 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#polymorphicInterface()}
032 *
033 * This can be used to build a whole update body
034 *
035 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#updateBodyInterface()}
036 *
037 * <h3 id="builder">Builder</h3>
038 *
039 * For each type a builder class exists. Each property can be set using the method with the property name at the builder instance. E.g.:
040 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#builderProperty()}
041 *
042 *
043 * <h4 id="object-builder">Object property</h4>
044 *
045 * If the property is an object type a method with a lambda function parameter is usable. The function is called with
046 * a builder instance of the properties type.
047 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#builderLambda()}
048 *
049 * <h4 id="array-builder">Array property</h4>
050 *
051 * Array properties have additional methods for adding addtional elements and build element instances.
052 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#builderArray()}
053 *
054 * <h4 id="polymorphic-builder">Polymorphic types</h4>
055 *
056 * Each polymorphic type builder provides methods for all it's subtype builders
057 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#polymorphicBuilder()}
058 *
059 * This can be used to build a whole update body
060 *
061 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#updateBodyBuilder()}
062
063 *
064 * <h3 id="impl">Implementation</h3>
065 *
066 * Each type has an implementation class (POJO). The class implements all properties of all interfaces and it's getters and setters.
067 * Also the implementation class implements an equals and hashcode method. The constructor is defined package private as
068 * new properties could be added by the API.
069 *
070 * The method `reflectionString` is available for all implementation classes by the {@link io.vrap.rmf.base.client.ModelBase} interface.
071 * This method will return a string representation of the instance.
072 *
073 * {@include.example example.ExamplesTest#reflectionString()}
074 */
075public class DataRepresentation {
076}
